If your marketing â€œisnâ€™t working,â€ Iâ€™d bet money itâ€™s not actually a marketing problem.

full_text:
3 marketing trends Iâ€™m betting on... & 1 Iâ€™m not buying ğŸ™…â€â™€ï¸ 

Marketing is evolving fast. We donâ€™t chase every shiny object at Accelity, buuuut we are paying close attention to the shifts that are changing how people connect with brands.

Hereâ€™s where Iâ€™d place my bets:

ğŸ‘¯ 1. Creator-driven content over brand-polished campaigns
Â 
People crave realness. Content that looks like it was made by a person performs better than the most polished brand assets. Weâ€™re leaning into user-generated content (UGC) and creators highlighting the human side of business (like Jackie Hermes, Dave Hersh, & Chris Heard).

ğŸ§  2. Strategy > Speed

 The days of â€œjust post moreâ€ are over ğŸ‘‹ . Whatâ€™s working now: slowing down to build brand depth and intention before layering on volume. Think about the content you have and how that can be repurposed instead of watering down your messages with similar, less powerful content. Our most successful campaigns are anchored in clarity, not juuust consistency. 

ğŸ’¬ 3. Conversation-led marketing

From social DMs to email replies, the best marketing today doesnâ€™t broadcastâ€”it invites responses. The brands winning right now are those that know how to listen just as well as they write and create a space for their followers to sound off.


ğŸš« And the one trend Iâ€™m ignoring:

ğŸ¤–  AI-generated eVeRtHiNg.

full_text:

We fixed our team culture with honesty (not perks).

ğŸ¥³ People tell us the hard stuff directly.

full_text:
Hiring based on your gut ğŸ¤°makes growing a small business HARD. 

Weâ€™ve been there.

And it cost us time, money, and, most importantly, trust. ğŸ˜• 

A few years ago at Accelity  we realized our hiring process wasnâ€™t working. Weâ€™d bring on someone based on potential, instinct, or what we thought we might need in the future.

The problem?

Sometimes we hired too early and didnâ€™t have enough work to support that person.

Other times, we waited too long and stretched our existing team too thin.
Both situations created stress. And both were *avoidable*.

So we got honest. And specific.

Hereâ€™s what we changed:

ğŸ”¢ We calculated actual workload.

We looked at billable hours by role and determined what a full-time plate should look like. That became our new baseline for hiring.

ğŸ“Š We tied hiring to real numbers.

When teams were consistently hitting or exceeding their billable targets and we saw work piling up, thatâ€™s when we started looking for the next hire, not before.

ğŸ§  We trained the team on the why.

We wanted everyone to understand how staffing decisions are made. It built trust and helped team members feel empowered to speak up when they were over capacity.

âš–ï¸ We created roles based on what was actually needed.

Not every new hire needs to be a unicorn. Sometimes you need a specialist, sometimes a generalist. But you wonâ€™t know unless you really assess the gaps.
That shiftâ€”from gut to groundedâ€”has helped us hire smarter, retain longer & protect our culture.

...because hiring isnâ€™t about filling a seat. Itâ€™s about creating the right fit for the team you have and the work ahead.

What am I missing? What hiring practices have helped your small businesses grow? Let's chat. :)

full_text:
Accountability sucksâ€¦ it shuts down our favorite excuses. ğŸ«  ğŸ˜… 

In reality, this isnâ€™t a punishment; it creates clear transparency. ğŸ”

Some people haaaate the word accountability (admittedly, early in my career, it wasnâ€™t my favorite concept).

It can sound a little like being called to the principalâ€™s office. ğŸ˜¬

So, early in my leadership career, I tended towards too much empathy and not enough accountability. I wanted people to like me, not fear me. I didnâ€™t hold myself accountable to leading as well as I could either.

ğŸ™€ Confusion.

ğŸ™€Frustration.

ğŸ™€And eventuallyâ€¦ burnout for everyone.

Set:

 âœ… Clear goals

 âœ… Clear expectations

 âœ… Clear ownership

Now, when something goes off-track, we talk about it openly. No blame. No shame. Everyone shows up and owns their part to determine how we fix the problem *together*.

Thatâ€™s what real accountability looks like. Fairness > Fear.

Itâ€™s amazing how much stronger a team becomes when everyone knows where they stand and whatâ€™s expected.

hook_150: Perfection kills trust.  I thought leadership meant always having ALL the right answers.  Leaders always have to be composed. They always need to know
full_text:
Perfection kills trust.

ğŸ”¹â€œI need a minute before I respond.â€

full_text:
Buyers purchase on > their < timelines, not ours. â±ï¸ 

And their buying journey looks more like a rollercoaster, not a straight line. AH! ğŸ¢
_
(This came up in my drafts again and felt worth resharing.)

Hereâ€™s an example of what this looked like for me and my super greens drink powder journey:

ğŸŒ± 2 years ago, I heard an in-podcast ad about a super greens drink supplement.

ğŸŒ± I researched and was not convinced that I should buy based on the price.

ğŸŒ± I put the supplement I wanted to buy in my shopping cart on the site, then abandoned it.

ğŸŒ± Ads on ads hit my social platforms (especially Instagram).

ğŸŒ± A year ago, my business partner, Jackie, shared that she takes a super greens drink supplement.

ğŸŒ± I looked at the website. I was then served supergreens drink options through social media ads.

ğŸŒ± 6 months ago, a co-worker shared she takes a greens drink supplement. I did more research.

ğŸŒ± I abandoned another shopping cart.

ğŸ˜´ A couple of months ago, I began feeling the 2 PM slump a lot harder than usual. It felt like I had a weight on my chest.

ğŸ’°Within a week of talking to my business partner, I purchased.

I nearly purchased several times. 

It became the *right* time to purchase when I felt that my PAIN, the symptom of my problem, needed to be addressed. The marketing messages I received each time informed my path to purchase and made it easier for me to click â€œBuy nowâ€ when I was ready.

Thatâ€™s how buyers buy. Not on our timelines, but on theirs. Itâ€™s our job to stay in front of them with the solution to their unique problem.
